#2

Rifts, and this one is personal.

I'm playing a technically D-Bee Glitter Boy pilot (He's one of the soldiers that survived the magic invasion by getting swallowed by a dimensional portal), and we were doing one of the adventure seeds from the monster book, the one where the players faced Godzilla. Effectively. That was also the session in which I got to cement my characters personality. He uses old (and older for him) quotes from various entertainment properties in combat.

This time it was Starcraft. Part of the CS patrol the heroes came across got hit bad with an 'Atomic Breath' attack (Bear in mind the GM cleverly never made mention that it was Godzilla, he just described it and made us wonder. I got lucky and realized it after.) so my walking tank takes a position so that the blast doesn't deafen allies. It's my turn:

"I'm gonna drop the hammer!" Pylons are engaged, counter brace engine spooling up "And dispense some indiscriminate justice!"

And then proceed to plink the next two high powered, MACH 5 accelerated shotgun blast on the giant beast's torso.

Now, I'm frustrated as the dice don't wanna play nice with me. Or so I was assuming, so I tell my GM that I'm aiming for his balls. I've given up and if I'm going to miss, I'm going to be silly about it! So I roll the dice. The D8 shooting gives me a 2. Yeap, expected. But the Wild Die says, "Hold up Hoss, where's a couple of 6s and a 2!" So I actually hit and got at least one raise out of it! Then the damage dice tells me, "Hoo, buddy, you'll be here a while!" And then proceeds to stun everyone with literally rolling so high that I stopped counting in the mid 60s, and realized that I had gotten something like 12 ranks of damage on Godzilla's literal ass.

So that one lucky roll meant that not only did I circumsize the biggest, meanest monster this side of Tokyo, I also misted his tail, ploughed the six forests BEHIND him and probably threw steel 'buckshot' so far Chi-Town has to repaint the wall a bit!

I only listed Rifts because I don't have any of the SWADE settings. Are there any out yet?

I'm getting back into Rippers (I found the conversion doc), I'm looking for my hard copy of Thrilling Tales.

OH! The Flash Gordon game! This is a solo game, because none of the other usual players like Flash Gordon (I'm like the only true pulp fan) so I'm playing a Power Man, an engineer that specializes in the Hydro Electric field. I actually tried to get Sanitation, but the GM said NO! I think she was assuming I was being silly. She was right. However, I've been really getting into him. He's a Mongo Man named Olm (Which is a play on Ohm, which I can get away with, because Flash Gordon's naming conventions says its OK.) He's a member of the Resistance, because Ming took his wife for his harem. Neither Ming nor anyone else, save the Power Man leader named Ergon, know this, though. It allows Olm to go places in Mingo City without arousing too much suspicion.

The main claim to fame is that Olm is both incredibly tough and strong, although he is pretty smart, his 6' 10" frame is what most people remember. That and his 'Martial Arts' is actually WWE style wrestling. The GM is a HUGE 90's wrestling fan, I get bennies whenever I use the more famous moves.

I've Stone Cold Stunned cavernosaurs (Two of them, crushing their skulls). Arm-barred his way through groups of Denizen (these were homebrewed minions, psychic rejects from the Imperial academies) who live in the sewers of Mingo City. German Suplexed most other critters, humanoid and others. And most of it has been done topless.

Oh, and inadvertently winning the heart of Queen Desira of Tropica. Which he can't really refuse, because then he'd have to tell why he hates Ming, which opens up to other people finding out... It's a glorious mess that I want to get back to.

Also, I second Streets of Bedlam suggestion AND if we're going to be going 3rd party, I'll add for those who like street level superhero stuff, I recommend the 'setting kit' Vigilante: Rise of The Powerless.

My Top 5 (in no particular order):

Rifts - I've always liked the Rifts settings, but not the rules. And they were too far removed to be readily converted. This implementation is great.

Powder Mage - I love the books and the world- Napoleonic military fiction with magic. More below.

Interface Zero - Great cyberpunk world

The Sixth Gun - I like the feel of the 6th gun a lot better than Deadlands, though it covers much of the same ground.

Tour of Darkness - Vietnam era horror- very useful for my Delta Green campaign set during that time.

It's hard to get it down to just 5- I don't play Savage Worlds, but I buy a lot for source material because many people are doing amazing things with the system, and SW to Fate isn't that far of a stretch in most cases.

Five others that on any given day might replace one of the above:

Necessary Evil - Villains save the world. Brilliant concept, well executed.

Lankhmar - It's Lankhmar! I'd also add Guild of Shadows.

Nova Praxis - A great Transhumanism sci-fi setting. So good, I have it twice.

Freeport - One of my favorite settings and goes very well with Lankhmar.

Ghost Ops - Modern day action/special ops.

WIthout any direct play experience, I really like The Day After Ragnarok, the post-apocalyptic pulp setting where you pick up the pieces after the Nazis conjured a giant magic snake at the end of WWII and dropped it on Europe. I agree with the general consensus that The Savage World of Solomon Kane was really well done - unfortunately it's out of print, which is the hazard of licensed games. Rippers would be a good choice to scratch the Gothic monster-hunting itch, albeit a couple centuries later. If your monster-hunting tastes run more towards gunplay, I heartily recommend Monster Hunter International. Finally, Heroes of Terra is a fantasy setting where inter-dimensional travelers from Earth fight malicious turtle-dragons on behalf of the humanoid fungi whose princess the reptiles have captured. It's really well thought out for such an outlandish premise.

chuckdee I've never heard of Powder Mage. What's its deal?

Powder Mage is based on a series of books by Brian McClellan, starting with the novel Promise of Blood. They are set in a universe of emerging techology (circa early 1800s, I'd say) that has very heavy use of magic in the setting. It reads in large part like military fiction. As far as magic, they have The Privileged, the Knacked, and Powder Mages.

The Knacked have a single magical talent that is sometimes useful in application, but never overly powerful. They might scent a lie, or never sleep, or be able to tell how much something weighs by picking it up.

The Privileged are the dominant magical force- not exceedingly rare, but rare enough that they hold much of the power. They are the closest to traditional magic users, and are feared in war and out of it, being able to manipulate energies from an alternate universe (the Else) to a variety of effects. They have a particular focus for their magic- their hands. The right hand draws power from the Else, and the left hand manipulates the effect.

Powder Mages (also called 'Marked') are somewhere between these two extremes, and are pretty much the leveling force against the Privileged. Instead of drawing power from the Else, they draw it from gunpowder. If they imbibe it, it makes them more of pretty much everything- stronger, faster, enduring, perceptive, etc. They can also manipulate gunpowder- the closer the better, but at distance too, making it explode- in large and small quantities. They can also redirect the location that the powder's force is felt, most often used to 'float' bullets, by causing the reaction of powder in their horn to nudge their bullets in flight.

Highly recommended.

Day After Ragnarok is not only my favorite Savage setting; it's one of my favorite settings, period. Good enough that I was entertaining a conversion during my brief SW burnout. Kenneth Hite pitched it as "Conan: 1948" but I feel "Rifts: 1948" might be a more accurate take.

Solomon Kane is the one that got me into SW and which served as the springboard for my longest running SW game, a Hyborian Age mini-campaign using SK magic, fan material and Mongoose d20 Conan setting books.

I have never played Necessary Evil but would love to. Villains-turned-heroes is a nice pitch that reminds me of the early Thunderbolts run.

Deadlands Reloaded I would use as the base for something a lot more nondescript than canon Deadlands. I'd be happy to raid The Sixth Gun for ideas as well.

Hellfrost and Shaintar have some interesting bits (I don't mind a little vanilla D&Desque fantasy but it's not something I usually have in mind when I reach for SW).

In the same vein, Realms of Cthulhu is something I used to think of as tantamount to heresy but after getting Achtung! Cthulhu and learning Baulderstone used RoC to run Masks of Nyarlathotep, I grudgingly admit it may be a good fit for a certain sort of Mythos game.

#32

What do you like about them?

Necessary Evil - I love that this is Supers, except you initially play on the opposite side. Not exactly Super Villains, but Super Rogues who get the chance to redeem themselves by becoming Super Heroes to save the world from an alien threat. It's also a self-contained campaign, with lots of opportunities for sandbox homebrews inbetween the metaplot. It's likely to be the most fun you'll ever have playing in the Supers genre

Thrilling Tales - Pure classic 1930s adventure, this is Indy Jones stuff and SW really hums at this level. Lots of good psuedo-historical content as well, it is the gold star for pulp adventure games.

50 Fathoms - This was an early SW plot point campaign which was really cool, mixing 17th Century style seafarers with fantasy elements. It is a self-contained campain, with a huge ammount of sandbox opportunities, and it is presented with a simplisitc charm to it.

Solomon Kane - This book is beautiful, the production, the artwork, and the fact that it is the only game that I know that uses Solomon Kane as a premises. I have never run it, but treasure this immensely.

Rippers - Again this is pulp adventure which SW does well. This time it's early Victorian era where you play members of a cabal of monster-hunters. This is pretty much straight out of the Hugh Jackson film 'Van Helsing' (or vice versa). Sort of if Hammer Horror did Steampunk - lot's of great opportunities here!

Deadlands Reloaded - The Weird West concept is a cool one, and Deadlands is the iconic game for it. Given that it was also kind of a forerunner to SW, it was good to see it ported into SW. These days I prefer to run Down Darker Trails (which is Weird West Call of Cthulhu), but Deadlands is still a book I would never part with.

Pirates of the Spanish Main - This is pretty much 'Pirates Of The Caribbean: The Game', so what is not to love here? It's a beautiful big book, it shows you how to run 18th Century buccaneers, and it has lots of content. These days I would actually run this with either BRP or Fate, but this book would still be a huge resource in many ways.

Wonderland No More - I have never played this, but it is also one of those books I really want to try out. It is Lewis Carroll's 'Wonderland' setting, and things have taken a turn for the worse. It's a surreal trippy fairy-tale setting that would make for unique stories.

In truth, I moved on from SW as a generic system, and returned to BRP, as well as stumbling across Fate Core.

I find I can do more with both BRP and Fate Core, and I prefer the mechanics - just personal preference.

However I have never felt that Evil Hat presented it's Fate Core settings and campaigns anywhere near half as good as Pinnacle does with it's SW settings.

I do not think I will part with any of the SW plot point campaigns, as they are quite an easy port to Fate Core, and they are so rich in content and useability.

I mean, the PC's were villains, so not everyone is going to believe that the PCs are heroes now. The amount of adventures you can have in that alone can last literal years after the initial set up.

Thrilling Tales - Pure classic 1930s adventure, this is Indy Jones stuff and SW really hums at this level. Lots of good psuedo-historical content as well, it is the gold star for pulp adventure games.

I also have a book, that I don't I remember the title of that details a 1920s where it's the after math of the War of The Worlds, which happened in the late 1890s.

Rippers - Again this is pulp adventure which SW does well. This time it's early Victorian era where you play members of a cabal of monster-hunters. This is pretty much straight out of the Hugh Jackson film 'Van Helsing' (or vice versa). Sort of if Hammer Horror did Steampunk - lot's of great opportunities here!

And Hansel and Gretel with Jeremy Renner, and other similar films of that era. A slight correction, 1895 is late Victorian.

Pirates! - This is pretty much 'Pirates Of The Caribbean: The Game', so what is not to love here? It's a beautiful big book, it shows you how to run buccaneers, and it has lots of content. These days I would actually run this with either BRP or Fate, but this book would still be a huge resource in many ways.

How could I forget Pirates of The Spanish Main??? Dear God. I ran a successful campaign for months with it! And several Convention games!

In truth, I moved on from SW as a generic system, and returned to BRP, as well as stumbling across Fate Core.

I find I can do more with both BRP and Fate Core, and I prefer the mechanics - just personal preference.

However I have never felt that Evil Hat presented it's Fate Core settings and campaigns anywhere near half as good as Pinnacle does with it's SW settings.

I do not think I will part with any of the SW plot point campaigns, as they are quite an easy port to Fate Core, and they are so rich in content and useability.

Deadlands - (especially the new edition). I literally hadn't played a western game in two-decades, until I discovered Deadlands. And I *love* it. The move away from the metaplot in the current edition is a big step in the right direction.

Savage Rifts - The system does so much honor to the original, and let's it breathe without tons and tons and tons of extra mechanics. You can engage in the heart of the gonzo without letting the game get in the way.

Hellfrost - Original. Fun. Tons of material. I'm really looking forward to a full SWADE edition I can hold in my hands.

Beasts & Barbarians - One of the BEST Hyborian analogues ever. Superb S&S setting. LOVE IT.

Pirates of the Spanish Main - Like B&B above, this setting is pure swashbuckling goodness. The setting is... the Spanish Main. What's not to love?

Rippers - I look at Rippers almost as a bookend to my Deadlands. It's wonderful. League of Extraordinary Badasses Darkside-mode.

I could probably name a couple of other honorable mentions... but these are probably my favorite.
